docTitle.titlePart: The Story of the Elder Monk
A Didactic Narrative on Discipline and Wisdom

div.head: Preface
div.p: This digital edition is intended as an example of how a traditional text may be represented in TEI XML. It is not a historical edition, but a teaching sample.

div.head: Chapter One: Arrival at the Monastery
div.p: In the valley below the snow mountains stood Serene Peak Monastery, where the Elder Monk taught the discipline of conduct and contemplation.
One autumn morning, a young novice named Jampa arrived from Cloud Valley. He bowed before the Abbot and said, Venerable sir, I wish to study the teachings and train my mind.

The abbot replied,
Study begins not with many words, but with careful attention. Stay near the Elder Monk, and observe how he walks, speaks, and keeps silence.
That evening, Jampa followed the elder to the assembly hall. On the wall hung an old inscription reading धर्म, explained in the margin by a later hand as teaching, law, reality.
div.note: The Sanskrit word here is intentionally brief to show how foreign-language elements may be marked.

div.head: Chapter Two: The Lesson of the Lamp
div.p: At dawn, the Elder Monk lit a butter lamp and placed it before an image of the Buddha. Seeing the novice watching, he asked, What do you see?

Jampa answered, I see the flame, bright and steady. The elder said,
Look again. The flame is steady only because it is constantly changing. In the same way, the mind seems continuous, yet every thought arises and passes.

The novice wrote these words in his notebook, but later the line was copied wrongly as
every thought arises and remains every thought arises and passes . An editor has corrected it here.
Outside, the wind moved through the pine trees of Pine Forest Hermitage. The elder recited the following verse:

lg.l: The lamp burns clear when guarded from the wind.
The mind grows clear when guarded from distraction.
One who watches rising and falling carefully
Finds peace not made by circumstances.

div.note: This verse is not from a canonical source; it is included here only as an example of verse encoding in TEI.

div.head: Chapter Three: The Journey to the Village
div.p: Some weeks later, the elder and the novice traveled to Cloud Valley to collect medicine for a sick monk. The path was steep, and the novice complained of hunger.

The Elder Monk said,
Hunger is known by the body, complaint is added by the mind. Learn to distinguish sensation from reaction.
Near the river they met a householder woman who offered them soup. Her name is lost in the manuscript; . She requested a blessing for her son.

The elder placed his hand above the child’s head and spoke gently. A later annotator added:
This passage is often cited in village preaching to illustrate compassion expressed through ordinary encounters.

In one witness of the text, the place name appears as
Cloud Valley Cloudvale , but this edition keeps the more common form.

div.head: Chapter Four: Unclear Words in the Night Teaching
div.p: On their return, the monks stopped at a small rest house. After sunset, Jampa asked, How can I know whether my practice is genuine?

The elder answered,
If pride increases, practice is weak. If greed increases, practice is crooked. If kindness increases, practice is maturing.
The manuscript becomes difficult to read here: one should test the heart in ordinary moments. The final phrase is partially damaged.

Another copy preserves the sentence more fully:
One should test the heart in ordinary moments, not only in meditation.
The novice then remained silent for a long time. In the morning he confessed that he had secretly wished to be praised for his discipline.
The Elder Monk smiled and replied, To see vanity is already to loosen its grip.

div.head: Chapter Five: The Abbot’s Instruction
div.p: Upon returning to Serene Peak Monastery, the novice reported what he had learned. The Abbot listened carefully and said:
He then commanded the novice to sweep the courtyard each morning for one year, adding that no instruction is complete until it enters the body through repetition.
A rubricated subheading in the manuscript reads: On the union of humility and diligence.
Some readers have taken this chapter as evidence that the novice later became a famous teacher, but the text itself does not say so. That conclusion belongs to later tradition.

div.head: Chapter Six: Colophon
div.p: Thus ends The Story of the Elder Monk, a narrative on the training of intention, patience, and insight.

closer.signed: Copied by a devoted student for the benefit of all beings.
